text:
So I get this, first thoughts are:
• can drop 4s by disabling logging (not sure if you have already done this?) 
• trade.complete is interesting, not sure why it is being called 9.3m times..
• `simulate.__bool__` is being called a lot, need to reduce this (3s)
• `SimulatedMiddleware` is slow, welcome any thoughts on this, C?
• `selection_exposure` is slow, can either look to cache it (like you did for size/price) or LRUCache the `calculate_exposure` function

elements.text: So I get this, first thoughts are:
can drop 4s by disabling logging (not sure if you have already done this?)
trade.complete is interesting, not sure why it is being called 9.3m times..
simulate.__bool__
is being called a lot, need to reduce this (3s)
SimulatedMiddleware
is slow, welcome any thoughts on this, C?
selection_exposure
is slow, can either look to cache it (like you did for size/price) or LRUCache the
calculate_exposure
function

text: I've been working with some larger data frames that are approximately ~5 GB when written to CSV. Pandas takes ages to write them to CSV but seconds to write them to h5 format. But then you lose the ease of readabiltiy e.g. being about to use `head`, `less`, `cat` and other UNIX command line tools. Was wondering if anyone else has experience of dealing with this

elements.text: I've been working with some larger data frames that are approximately ~5 GB when written to CSV. Pandas takes ages to write them to CSV but seconds to write them to h5 format. But then you lose the ease of readabiltiy e.g. being about to use
head
less
cat
and other UNIX command line tools. Was wondering if anyone else has experience of dealing with this

text: One possible solution might be to write a CSV in memory and compress it (gzip) prior to writing to disc (and you can use `zcat` to access the data via the terminal). I think numpy even has a function that can save the array directly as a zipped file but not sure if it transforms it to some prop format before zipping it (rather than -> CSV > zip).

elements.text: One possible solution might be to write a CSV in memory and compress it (gzip) prior to writing to disc (and you can use `zcat` to access the data via the terminal). I think numpy even has a function that can save the array directly as a zipped file but not sure if it transforms it to some prop format before zipping it (rather than -> CSV > zip).

text: Yeah unfortunately I don't think a "hdf5cat" exists, probably because you typically store multiple arrays of n dimensions (rather than a 2D CSV). Might be worth whipping up a quick utility in python for your use case. :white_frowning_face:

text:
I thought he had the reason of needing taxable income to stay in the country. Seems plausible to me. 

Perhaps he thinks no one will be good enough to compete with him even with a training course. 

I do think manual trading and automated trading are two different worlds. Automated trading has clear edges to give away, whereas manual can be a mixture of things which are less definable - intuition, reading markets, reading game momentum, reaction speed, etc... as well as analytics and stats.

elements.text: I thought he had the reason of needing taxable income to stay in the country. Seems plausible to me.
Perhaps he thinks no one will be good enough to compete with him even with a training course.

I do think manual trading and automated trading are two different worlds. Automated trading has clear edges to give away, whereas manual can be a mixture of things which are less definable - intuition, reading markets, reading game momentum, reaction speed, etc... as well as analytics and stats.

text: Yeah that’s what I’m thinking

text:
In a way, us replying to threads on a “strategy” channel is effectively “training” competitors. I’m sure there’s info on there people would have paid for. We choose not to charge for it, but I don’t think whether we do or don’t reflects on whether we are really profitable or not. Maybe we’re just more generous? :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye: But again, maybe he does have a legitimate reason. 

Anyway, I stay open minded about what people can do in sports betting. I wouldn’t have believed myself if I told myself 10 years ago what I’d be able to do now.

text: Hdf5 is great if your data is purely numerical, but otherwise can be a bit of a pain

text: Also you generally want a very tabular format.

text: I've moved from hdf5 to parquet in other parts of my life as it's more modern and implicitly reads files using multiple cores, so the reads are nice and quick in an age where loading data is often cpu bound on the decompression +conversion to pandas obj end

elements.text: I've moved from hdf5 to parquet in other parts of my life as it's more modern and implicitly reads files using multiple cores, so the reads are nice and quick in an age where loading data is often cpu bound on the decompression +conversion to pandas obj end

text: hdf5 feels like somewhat of a hold-out from the past where we only had terrible file-systems, it's basically a file systyem in software form. We've moved on from then!

text: Yes. The code iterates through the full iterable of orders with every market book update. This can be seen in backtest/backtest.py

elements.text: Yes. The code iterates through the full iterable of orders with every market book update. This can be seen in backtest/backtest.py

text: I've been experimenting with tracking completed trades in my personal strategy code, and therefore being able to quickly find executable trades.

elements.text: I've been experimenting with tracking completed trades in my personal strategy code, and therefore being able to quickly find executable trades.

text:
Basically, Blotter._orders is a dict, keyed on the bet id. Dict keys are like sets, so you can do diffs on them very quickly.

So when an order is completed, you can add it to your set of completed order ids for small cost. And then when you want your live orders, you can do something like:

active_bet_ids = set(blotter._orders().keys) - completed_order_ids_

elements.text:
Basically, Blotter._orders is a dict, keyed on the bet id. Dict keys are like sets, so you can do diffs on them very quickly.

So when an order is completed, you can add it to your set of completed order ids for small cost. And then when you want your live orders, you can do something like:

active_bet_ids = set(blotter.
orders().keys) - completed_order_ids

text: active_orders = [blotter[aid] for aid in active_bet_ids]

elements.text: active_orders = [blotter[aid] for aid in active_bet_ids]

text: (alll that above is from the top of my head, so please take it with a pinch of salt). But in my testing yesterday, it had a pretty trivial cost.

elements.text: (alll that above is from the top of my head, so please take it with a pinch of salt). But in my testing yesterday, it had a pretty trivial cost.

text:
It's related to how Python works. Under the hood, doing a set difference is probably doing some C-level fast code.

If we do something like [x for x in blotter where x.status=='EXECUTABLE'], it has to go through slow Python code every time it looks at x.status.

elements.text:
It's related to how Python works. Under the hood, doing a set difference is probably doing some C-level fast code.

If we do something like [x for x in blotter where x.status=='EXECUTABLE'], it has to go through slow Python code every time it looks at x.status.

text:
I agree with everything you say and at the same time I’m sort of consciously hypocritical about it. 

I think I’m slightly biased though, because I fall into that small category of people who have been successful having been inspired by other people, whether they were/are real or not. If I weren’t inspired them I don’t think I’d have got into sports betting and won as much as I have. 

I also personally feel that what I/we do as winning professionals is a bit of a grey area in itself. We essentially win money from people stupid enough to bet against us. Perhaps they gain some entertainment value, but essentially they are sold the idea of winning, but they won’t in the long run. At the same time I continue to do it for a living. So even though I feel that I want to cast judgement on others doing possibly questionable things like selling courses, I personally don’t feel like I’m in a position to do so.

elements.text: I agree with everything you say and at the same time I’m sort of consciously hypocritical about it.

I also personally feel that what I/we do as winning professionals is a bit of a grey area in itself. We essentially win money from people stupid enough to bet against us. Perhaps they gain some entertainment value, but essentially they are sold the idea of winning, but they won’t in the long run. At the same time I continue to do it for a living. So even though I feel that I want to cast judgement on others doing possibly questionable things like selling courses, I personally don’t feel like I’m in a position to do so.
